title: 113_s743
content:
The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" authorizes the collection of sales and use taxes. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows Member States under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement to require sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales. Non-Member States have an alternative option. States may exercise authority under the Act 180 days after publishing notice, but no earlier than 180 days after enactment. Non-Member States can require sellers to collect sales taxes for remote sales if they adopt minimum simplification requirements. States can exercise authority under the Act after 180 days of notice, but not before 180 days of enactment. Non-Member States can mandate sellers to collect sales taxes for remote sales by meeting minimum simplification requirements, including specifying applicable taxes and providing a single entity within the State. The Act allows States to impose taxes on remote sales by meeting minimum simplification requirements, including designating a single entity for tax administration, audits, and return processing. The Act allows remote sellers to undergo a single audit for all State and local taxing jurisdictions and file a single sales and use tax return with a designated entity. States cannot require remote sellers to file tax returns more frequently than nonremote sellers or impose additional requirements. Local jurisdictions cannot require remote sellers to submit tax returns or collect taxes beyond what is required for nonremote sellers. The Act mandates uniform sales and use tax requirements for remote sellers, including sourcing all remote sales in compliance with set definitions and providing information on taxability of products and services. The Act requires remote sellers to comply with sourcing definitions and provide information on taxability of products and services, along with software for calculating and filing sales and use taxes. The Act requires remote sellers to use certified software providers for calculating and filing sales and use taxes in all qualified States, relieving them from liability for any errors in tax collection or remittance. The Act requires remote sellers to use certified software providers for tax calculations and filings in qualified States, relieving them from liability for errors in tax collection or remittance. The Act relieves remote sellers and certified software providers from liability for incorrect tax collection or remittance due to misleading information. It also requires a 90-day notice of rate changes by the State or locality. The Act allows States to require remote sellers to collect sales taxes only if their total remote sales exceed $1,000,000 in the previous year. It also mandates a 90-day notice for rate changes by the State or locality to remote sellers and software providers, relieving them from liability for collecting taxes at the previous rate during the notice period if not provided. The Small Seller Exception in the Act authorizes States to require remote sellers to collect sales taxes only if their total remote sales exceed $1,000,000 in the previous year. Gross annual receipts from remote sales of related persons may be aggregated to meet the threshold, with ownership relationships designed to avoid these rules also considered. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS. 

(a) In General.--This Act does not subject sellers to various taxes other than sales and use taxes, does not affect tax application, and does not change State authority to impose taxes. 
(b) No Effect on Nexus.--The Act does not create nexus or change nexus standards between a person and a State or locality. 
(c) No Effect on Seller Choice.--Remote sellers can still choose their certified software provider. 
(d) Licensing and Regulatory Requirements.--States can still license and regulate individuals and require qualifications for intrastate transactions. The Act allows remote sellers to use their chosen certified software provider and does not affect state licensing, regulatory requirements, or intrastate sales. It also does not encourage new taxes or impose sales taxes on untaxed products or services. The Act does not encourage new taxes or impose sales taxes on untaxed products or services. It applies only to remote sales and does not affect intrastate sales or the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. In this Act, a certified software provider is defined as a person who provides software to remote sellers for tax compliance and is certified by a State. The terms "locality" and "local" refer to any political subdivision of a State. A Member State is defined as a state under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement, excluding associate members. In this Act, a Member State is defined as a state under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement, excluding associate members. A person is defined as an individual, trust, estate, partnership, corporation, or other legal entity. A remote sale refers to a sale into a State where the seller is not legally required to pay, collect, or remit State or local sales and use taxes unless provided by this Act. A remote sale is defined as a sale into a State where the seller is not legally required to pay, collect, or remit State or local sales and use taxes unless provided by this Act. A remote seller is a person that makes remote sales in the State. The location to which a remote sale is sourced refers to where the product or service sold is received by the purchaser, based on delivery instructions provided by the purchaser. If no delivery location is specified, the remote sale is sourced to the customer's address. The sourcing of a remote sale is based on the delivery instructions provided by the purchaser. If no specific delivery location is given, the sale is sourced to the customer's address. If the address is unknown, the sale is sourced to the seller's address. States granted authority must comply with the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. The billing address cannot be obtained, so the remote sale is sourced to the seller's address. States granted authority must comply with the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. The term "Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement" refers to a multi-State agreement adopted on November 12, 2002, and further amended, applicable to States granted authority for remote sales sourced to the seller's address. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. SEC. 6. PREEMPTION. This Act does not limit any powers of State or local jurisdictions unless specified otherwise.
